title: Thomas S. Noonan
text:
Thomas Schaub Noonan (January 20, 1938 – June 15, 2001) was an <a href="United%20States%20of%20America">American</a> historian, <a href="Slavicist">Slavicist</a> and <a href="anthropology">anthropologist</a> who specialized in early <a href="Russian%20history">Russian history</a> and <a href="Eurasian%20nomad">Eurasian nomad</a> cultures.
Educated at <a href="Indiana%20University">Indiana University</a>, Noonan was, for many years, a <a href="Professor">Professor</a> of History at the <a href="University%20of%20Minnesota">University of Minnesota</a>. He was the author of dozens of books and articles and one of the leading authorities on the development of the <a href="Kievan%20Rus">Kievan Rus</a> and the <a href="Khazar">Khazar</a> <a href="Khaganate">Khaganate</a>. Noonan placed a great deal of importance on <a href="numismatics">numismatics</a> in understanding economic and social trends. He was the mentor of numerous scholars and leading historians. In 2001 many of his colleagues honored him by publishing the first of a multivolume collection of articles under the title "<a href="Festschrift">Festschrift</a> in Honor of Thomas S. Noonan," which was edited by Roman K. Kovalev and Heidi M. Sherman. The second volume appeared in 2005.
Noonan died of <a href="cancer">cancer</a> in 2001.
